pairs.stoic_text:
When you set about any action, remind yourself of what nature the action
is. If you are going to bathe, represent to yourself the incidents usual
in the bath—some persons pouring out, others pushing in, others scolding,
others pilfering. And thus you will more safely go about this action if
you say to yourself, “I will now go to bathe and keep my own will in
harmony with nature.” And so with regard to every other action. For thus,
if any impediment arises in bathing, you will be able to say, “It was not
only to bathe that I desired, but to keep my will in harmony with nature;
and I shall not keep it thus if I am out of humor at things that happen.”
pairs.neutral_text: Before you do anything, think about what that activity typically involves. If you're going to take a bath, remember what usually happens at public baths—some people are leaving, others are pushing to get in, some are arguing, and others are stealing. You'll handle the situation better if you tell yourself, "I'm going to bathe and stay calm about whatever happens." Do this same preparation for every activity. This way, if something goes wrong while you're bathing, you can remind yourself, "I didn't just come here to bathe. I came here to stay calm no matter what happens. If I get angry about these problems, I'm failing at my real goal."

pairs.stoic_text:
Begin therefore with little things. Is a little oil spilled or a little
wine stolen? Say to yourself, “This is the price paid for peace and
tranquillity; and nothing is to be had for nothing.” And when you call
your servant, consider that it is possible he may not come at your call;
or, if he does, that he may not do what you wish. But it is not at all
desirable for him, and very undesirable for you, that it should be in his
power to cause you any disturbance.
pairs.neutral_text: Start with small problems. If some oil gets spilled or someone steals a little wine, tell yourself that this is what you pay for staying calm and peaceful - everything has a cost. When you call your servant, remember that he might not come when you call him, or if he does come, he might not do what you want. But it wouldn't be good for him to have the ability to upset you, and it would be very bad for you if he could.

pairs.stoic_text:
In the Stoic distinctions of personality and world, of I and mine, of
subjective consciousness and the world of objects, of freedom and
dependence, we find implicit the basic elements of modern philosophies of
rationalism and of objective idealism or pantheism. For this reason there
is a continuous renascence of Stoicism from Descartes, Grotius, and
Bishop Butler, to Montesquieu, Adam Smith, and Kant. In this long
development in modern times, the tiny _Enchiridion_ of Epictetus played a
remarkable part.
pairs.neutral_text:
The Stoics made clear separations between personality and the world, between "I" and "what belongs to me," between personal awareness and external objects, and between freedom and dependence. These basic ideas formed the foundation for later rational philosophy and the philosophical view that everything is part of one universal mind or spirit.

Because of this foundation, Stoic ideas have repeatedly influenced philosophy from the time of Descartes, Grotius, and Bishop Butler through Montesquieu, Adam Smith, and Kant. Throughout this long period of modern philosophical development, Epictetus's short work called the _Enchiridion_ had significant influence.

pairs.stoic_text:
The body is to everyone the proper measure of its possessions, as the
foot is of the shoe. If, therefore, you stop at this, you will keep the
measure; but if you move beyond it, you must necessarily be carried
forward, as down a precipice; as in the case of a shoe, if you go beyond
its fitness to the foot, it comes first to be gilded, then purple, and
then studded with jewels. For to that which once exceeds the fit measure
there is no bound.
pairs.neutral_text: Your body's needs should determine what you own, just like your foot determines what size shoe you need. If you stick to this rule, you'll have the right amount of things. But if you want more than what your body actually needs, you'll keep wanting more and more without being able to stop. This is like making shoes that are too big for your feet - first you might decorate them with gold, then make them purple, then add jewels. Once you go beyond what you actually need, there's no natural stopping point.

pairs.stoic_text:
Men are disturbed not by things, but by the views which they take of
things. Thus death is nothing terrible, else it would have appeared so to
Socrates. But the terror consists in our notion of death, that it is
terrible. When, therefore, we are hindered or disturbed, or grieved, let
us never impute it to others, but to ourselves—that is, to our own views.
It is the action of an uninstructed person to reproach others for his own
misfortunes; of one entering upon instruction, to reproach himself; and
one perfectly instructed, to reproach neither others nor himself.
pairs.neutral_text:
People get upset by their opinions about events, not by the events themselves. For example, death isn't scary by nature - if it were, Socrates would have been afraid of it too. The fear comes from our belief that death is something to be afraid of. 

When we feel blocked, upset, or sad, we shouldn't blame other people. Instead, we should recognize that our own thoughts and beliefs are causing these feelings.

People who haven't learned this principle blame others when bad things happen to them. People who are starting to learn this principle blame themselves. People who have fully learned this principle don't blame anyone at all.

pairs.stoic_text:
Be mostly silent, or speak merely what is needful, and in few words. We
may, however, enter sparingly into discourse sometimes, when occasion
calls for it; but let it not run on any of the common subjects, as
gladiators, or horse races, or athletic champions, or food, or drink—the
vulgar topics of conversation—and especially not on men, so as either to
blame, or praise, or make comparisons. If you are able, then, by your own
conversation, bring over that of your company to proper subjects; but if
you happen to find yourself among strangers, be silent.
pairs.neutral_text: Stay quiet most of the time, or only say what's necessary using few words. You can have conversations occasionally when the situation requires it, but don't talk about ordinary topics like gladiator fights, horse racing, sports, food, or drinks—these are common conversation subjects. Especially avoid talking about other people in ways that criticize them, praise them, or compare them to others. If you can, try to steer your group's conversation toward more appropriate topics through your own comments. If you're with people you don't know, don't say anything.

pairs.stoic_text:
When you are going before anyone in power, fancy to yourself that you may
not find him at home, that you may be shut out, that the doors may not be
opened to you, that he may not notice you. If, with all this, it be your
duty to go, bear what happens and never say to yourself, “It was not
worth so much”; for this is vulgar, and like a man bewildered by
externals.
pairs.neutral_text: When you need to meet with someone in authority, prepare yourself for possible problems. They might not be available, you might not be allowed in, the doors could be closed to you, or they might ignore you. If you still have to go despite these possibilities, accept whatever happens without complaining that "it wasn't worth the trouble." Complaining like this is crude and shows you're too focused on things outside your control.

pairs.stoic_text:
When anyone shows himself vain on being able to understand and interpret
the works of Chrysippus,[7] say to yourself: “Unless Chrysippus had
written obscurely, this person would have had nothing to be vain of. But
what do I desire? To understand nature, and follow her. I ask, then, who
interprets her; and hearing that Chrysippus does, I have recourse to him.
I do not understand his writings. I seek, therefore, one to interpret
_them_.” So far there is nothing to value myself upon. And when I find an
interpreter, what remains is to make use of his instructions. This alone
is the valuable thing. But if I admire merely the interpretation, what do
I become more than a grammarian, instead of a philosopher, except,
indeed, that instead of Homer I interpret Chrysippus? When anyone,
therefore, desires me to read Chrysippus to him, I rather blush when I
cannot exhibit actions that are harmonious and consonant with his
discourse.
pairs.neutral_text: When someone brags about being able to understand and explain Chrysippus's writings, tell yourself this: "If Chrysippus had written clearly, this person would have nothing to brag about. But what do I want? I want to understand nature and live according to it. I ask who can explain nature to me, and I'm told that Chrysippus can, so I go to him. I don't understand his writings, so I look for someone to explain them to me." There's nothing to be proud of so far. When I find someone to explain the writings, what matters is using those teachings. That's the only valuable part. If I only care about understanding the explanations, I become just a scholar who studies texts instead of a philosopher - the only difference is that I study Chrysippus instead of Homer. So when someone asks me to read Chrysippus to them, I feel embarrassed when my actions don't match what his teachings say I should do.

pairs.stoic_text:
If you would improve, lay aside such reasonings as these: “If I neglect
my affairs, I shall not have a maintenance; if I do not punish my
servant, he will be good for nothing.” For it were better to die of
hunger, exempt from grief and fear, than to live in affluence with
perturbation; and it is better that your servant should be bad than you
unhappy.
pairs.neutral_text:
If you want to get better at philosophy, stop thinking like this: "If I don't take care of my business, I won't have money to live on. If I don't discipline my servant, he won't do his job properly."

It's better to starve to death without worry and fear than to be wealthy but constantly anxious. It's also better for your servant to behave badly than for you to be miserable.

pairs.stoic_text:
If you are dazzled by the semblance of any promised pleasure, guard
yourself against being bewildered by it; but let the affair wait your
leisure, and procure yourself some delay. Then bring to your mind both
points of time—that in which you shall enjoy the pleasure, and that in
which you will repent and reproach yourself, after you have enjoyed
it—and set before you, in opposition to these, how you will rejoice and
applaud yourself if you abstain. And even though it should appear to you
a seasonable gratification, take heed that its enticements and
allurements and seductions may not subdue you, but set in opposition to
this how much better it is to be conscious of having gained so great a
victory.
pairs.neutral_text: If you're tempted by something that seems pleasurable, don't let it confuse you. Instead, take time to think about it carefully. Consider two future moments: first, when you would experience the pleasure, and second, when you would later feel regret and blame yourself afterward. Compare these to how good you would feel about yourself if you resist the temptation. Even if the pleasure seems appropriate at the time, be careful not to let its appeal overcome your judgment. Remember that it's better to be aware that you've won an important personal victory by resisting.

pairs.stoic_text:
When you see anyone weeping for grief, either that his son has gone
abroad or that he has suffered in his affairs, take care not to be
overcome by the apparent evil, but discriminate and be ready to say,
“What hurts this man is not this occurrence itself—for another man might
not be hurt by it—but the view he chooses to take of it.” As far as
conversation goes, however, do not disdain to accommodate yourself to him
and, if need be, to groan with him. Take heed, however, not to groan
inwardly, too.
pairs.neutral_text:
When you see someone crying because their child has moved away or they've had problems with money or work, don't let their apparent suffering affect your own emotions. Remember that the actual event isn't what's causing their pain—someone else might not be upset by the same situation. Their suffering comes from how they choose to interpret what happened. 

When talking to them, you should still be considerate and sympathetic. You can even express sympathy out loud if it seems appropriate. Just make sure you don't actually start feeling upset yourself on the inside.

pairs.stoic_text:
In company, avoid a frequent and excessive mention of your own actions
and dangers. For however agreeable it may be to yourself to allude to the
risks you have run, it is not equally agreeable to others to hear your
adventures. Avoid likewise an endeavor to excite laughter, for this may
readily slide you into vulgarity, and, besides, may be apt to lower you
in the esteem of your acquaintance. Approaches to indecent discourse are
likewise dangerous. Therefore, when anything of this sort happens, use
the first fit opportunity to rebuke him who makes advances that way, or,
at least, by silence and blushing and a serious look show yourself to be
displeased by such talk.
pairs.neutral_text:
When you're with other people, don't talk too much about things you've done or dangerous situations you've been in. You might enjoy talking about your experiences, but others don't necessarily want to hear about them all the time.

Also, don't try too hard to make people laugh. This can lead you to say inappropriate things and might cause people to think less of you.

Be careful around conversations that become inappropriate or offensive. When this happens, either speak up against the person who started it, or show that you disapprove by staying quiet, looking uncomfortable, and acting serious.

pairs.stoic_text:
You can be unconquerable if you enter into no combat in which it is not
in your own power to conquer. When, therefore, you see anyone eminent in
honors or power, or in high esteem on any other account, take heed not to
be bewildered by appearances and to pronounce him happy; for if the
essence of good consists in things within our own power, there will be no
room for envy or emulation. But, for your part, do not desire to be a
general, or a senator, or a consul, but to be free; and the only way to
this is a disregard of things which lie not within our own power.
pairs.neutral_text: You cannot be defeated if you only engage in battles you can win. When you see someone who has high status, power, or is well-respected, don't be fooled by how things appear and assume they are truly happy. If what is truly good comes only from things you can control, then there is no reason to be jealous or try to compete with others. Instead of wanting to become a general, senator, or consul, focus on being free. The only way to achieve this freedom is to stop caring about things you cannot control.

pairs.stoic_text:
Avoid public and vulgar entertainments; but if ever an occasion calls you
to them, keep your attention upon the stretch, that you may not
imperceptibly slide into vulgarity. For be assured that if a person be
ever so pure himself, yet, if his companion be corrupted, he who
converses with him will be corrupted likewise.
pairs.neutral_text: Don't attend popular, crude forms of entertainment. If you must go to such events, stay mentally alert so you don't gradually adopt crude behavior without realizing it. Remember that even if you are a good person, spending time with people who behave badly will cause you to behave badly too.

pairs.stoic_text:
These reasonings have no logical connection: “I am richer than you,
therefore I am your superior.” “I am more eloquent than you, therefore I
am your superior.” The true logical connection is rather this: “I am
richer than you, therefore my possessions must exceed yours.” “I am more
eloquent than you, therefore my style must surpass yours.” But you, after
all, consist neither in property nor in style.
pairs.neutral_text: These arguments don't make logical sense: "I have more money than you, so I'm better than you." "I speak better than you, so I'm better than you." The correct logical connections would be: "I have more money than you, so I own more things than you." "I speak better than you, so my speaking ability is better than yours." But a person's worth isn't determined by how much they own or how well they speak.

pairs.stoic_text:
If you have an earnest desire toward philosophy, prepare yourself from
the very first to have the multitude laugh and sneer, and say, “He is
returned to us a philosopher all at once”; and, “Whence this supercilious
look?” Now, for your part, do not have a supercilious look indeed, but
keep steadily to those things which appear best to you, as one appointed
by God to this particular station. For remember that, if you are
persistent, those very persons who at first ridiculed will afterwards
admire you. But if you are conquered by them, you will incur a double
ridicule.
pairs.neutral_text: If you seriously want to study philosophy, be ready for people to mock you from the beginning. They will laugh at you and say things like "Look, he thinks he's a philosopher now" and "Why does he act so superior?" Don't actually act superior, but stick to what you believe is right, like someone who has been given this job by God. Remember that if you don't give up, the same people who made fun of you at first will respect you later. But if you let them discourage you, they will mock you even more.

pairs.stoic_text:
Now the things within our power are by nature free, unrestricted,
unhindered; but those beyond our power are weak, dependent, restricted,
alien. Remember, then, that if you attribute freedom to things by nature
dependent and take what belongs to others for your own, you will be
hindered, you will lament, you will be disturbed, you will find fault
both with gods and men. But if you take for your own only that which is
your own and view what belongs to others just as it really is, then no
one will ever compel you, no one will restrict you; you will find fault
with no one, you will accuse no one, you will do nothing against your
will; no one will hurt you, you will not have an enemy, nor will you
suffer any harm.
pairs.neutral_text:
Some things are under your control, and some things are not. The things you can control are naturally free and unrestricted. The things you cannot control are limited and depend on external factors.

If you mistakenly think you can control things that are actually outside your control, or if you try to claim things that belong to other people, you will face obstacles, feel upset, and become disturbed. You will blame both gods and other people for your problems.

However, if you only focus on what truly belongs to you and see other people's possessions as theirs (not yours), then no one can force you to do anything or limit you. You will not blame anyone or accuse anyone of wrongdoing. You will not act against your own wishes. No one will be able to hurt you, you will not have enemies, and you will not experience harm.

pairs.stoic_text:
When any person does ill by you, or speaks ill of you, remember that he
acts or speaks from an impression that it is right for him to do so. Now
it is not possible that he should follow what appears right to you, but
only what appears so to himself. Therefore, if he judges from false
appearances, he is the person hurt, since he, too, is the person
deceived. For if anyone takes a true proposition to be false, the
proposition is not hurt, but only the man is deceived. Setting out, then,
from these principles, you will meekly bear with a person who reviles
you, for you will say upon every occasion, “It seemed so to him.”
pairs.neutral_text: When someone treats you badly or says negative things about you, remember that they believe their actions are justified. They can't follow what you think is right - they can only follow what they think is right. If their beliefs are wrong, they're the ones being harmed because they're mistaken about the situation. When someone believes something false, the truth isn't damaged - only the person who believes the falsehood is hurt by their mistake. If you understand this, you'll be able to stay calm when someone criticizes you, because you'll remind yourself that they're acting based on how things appear to them.

pairs.stoic_text:
When you have learned to nourish your body frugally, do not pique
yourself upon it; nor, if you drink water, be saying upon every occasion,
“I drink water.” But first consider how much more frugal are the poor
than we, and how much more patient of hardship. If at any time you would
inure yourself by exercise to labor and privation, for your own sake and
not for the public, do not attempt great feats; but when you are
violently thirsty, just rinse your mouth with water, and tell nobody.
pairs.neutral_text:
When you learn to eat simply and spend less money on food, don't be proud of it or show off about it. If you choose to drink only water, don't tell everyone "I drink water" all the time. Remember that poor people live with much less than we do and handle difficult conditions better than we can.

If you want to train yourself to work hard and go without things, do it for your own benefit, not to impress other people. Don't try to do extreme things. For example, when you're very thirsty, just rinse your mouth with water instead of drinking, and don't tell anyone about it.

pairs.stoic_text:
Aiming, therefore, at such great things, remember that you must not allow
yourself any inclination, however slight, toward the attainment of the
others; but that you must entirely quit some of them, and for the present
postpone the rest. But if you would have these, and possess power and
wealth likewise, you may miss the latter in seeking the former; and you
will certainly fail of that by which alone happiness and freedom are
procured.
pairs.neutral_text: When working toward important goals, remember that you cannot pursue everything at once. You must give up some objectives completely and delay others for now. If you try to achieve these meaningful goals while also seeking power and wealth, you will likely fail to get the power and wealth, and you will definitely fail to achieve the things that actually bring happiness and freedom.

pairs.stoic_text:
As in a voyage, when the ship is at anchor, if you go on shore to get
water, you may amuse yourself with picking up a shellfish or a truffle in
your way, but your thoughts ought to be bent toward the ship, and
perpetually attentive, lest the captain should call, and then you must
leave all these things, that you may not have to be carried on board the
vessel, bound like a sheep; thus likewise in life, if, instead of a
truffle or shellfish, such a thing as a wife or a child be granted you,
there is no objection; but if the captain calls, run to the ship, leave
all these things, and never look behind. But if you are old, never go far
from the ship, lest you should be missing when called for.
pairs.neutral_text:
When a ship is anchored and you go on shore to get water, you can pick up shells or other small items along the way. However, you should keep watching for the ship and stay alert for the captain's call. If the captain calls and you're not ready, you'll be forced onto the ship against your will.

Life works the same way. It's fine to have a spouse or children instead of just collecting shells. But when it's time to go, you must be ready to leave everything behind immediately without hesitation. If you're old, don't get too involved in these attachments because you might not have much time left when you're called to leave.

pairs.stoic_text:
It is not necessary for you to appear often at public spectacles; but if
ever there is a proper occasion for you to be there, do not appear more
solicitous for any other than for yourself—that is, wish things to be
only just as they are, and only the best man to win; for thus nothing
will go against you. But abstain entirely from acclamations and derision
and violent emotions. And when you come away, do not discourse a great
deal on what has passed and what contributes nothing to your own
amendment. For it would appear by such discourse that you were dazzled by
the show.
pairs.neutral_text: You don't need to attend public events very often. When you do go to appropriate events, don't favor any particular participant over others. Instead, accept whatever happens and hope that the most deserving person wins. This way you won't be disappointed by the results. Don't cheer loudly, mock anyone, or get overly emotional. After the event, don't spend a lot of time talking about what happened, since this won't help you improve yourself. Talking too much about the event shows that you were overly impressed by it.

pairs.stoic_text:
With regard to whatever objects either delight the mind or contribute to
use or are tenderly beloved, remind yourself of what nature they are,
beginning with the merest trifles: if you have a favorite cup, that it is
but a cup of which you are fond of—for thus, if it is broken, you can
bear it; if you embrace your child or your wife, that you embrace a
mortal—and thus, if either of them dies, you can bear it.
pairs.neutral_text: When you enjoy something, find it useful, or love it deeply, remember what it actually is. Start with small things: if you have a cup you really like, remember that it's just a cup you happen to enjoy. This way, if it breaks, you won't be devastated. When you hug your child or spouse, remember that they are human and will eventually die. If you keep this in mind, you'll be better able to cope when they do die.

pairs.stoic_text:
Upon every accident, remember to turn toward yourself and inquire what
faculty you have for its use. If you encounter a handsome person, you
will find continence the faculty needed; if pain, then fortitude; if
reviling, then patience. And when thus habituated, the phenomena of
existence will not overwhelm you.
pairs.neutral_text: When something happens to you, ask yourself what ability you need to handle it. If you meet an attractive person, you'll need self-control. If you experience pain, you'll need courage. If someone insults you, you'll need patience. If you practice this regularly, life's events won't overpower you.

pairs.stoic_text:
Remember that it is not he who gives abuse or blows, who affronts, but
the view we take of these things as insulting. When, therefore, anyone
provokes you, be assured that it is your own opinion which provokes you.
Try, therefore, in the first place, not to be bewildered by appearances.
For if you once gain time and respite, you will more easily command
yourself.
pairs.neutral_text:
When someone insults you or hits you, they are not actually causing you to feel offended. Your feelings come from how you interpret what they did. So when someone makes you angry, remember that your reaction comes from your own thoughts about what happened, not from their actions directly.

First, try not to let the situation confuse you or make you react immediately. If you can pause and give yourself some time to think, it will be easier to control your response.

pairs.stoic_text:
Thus we do not have any original writings of Epictetus. Like G. H. Mead
in recent times, he was completely dedicated to the human and
intellectual problems of his students. He left it for them to preserve
what they considered to be the lasting message of the teacher. In
contrast to Seneca and Marcus Aurelius, Epictetus had no subjective
approach to the Stoic doctrines. Moral philosophy was the center of his
teaching, and epistemology was only instrumental. It is even permissible
to say that he took physics or cosmology too lightly. If this is granted,
we must admit that he is completely absorbed by the fundamentals of Stoic
thought as presented in the _Enchiridion_. Epictetus’ personality is
totally integrated in the act of reasoning which establishes conformity
with nature.
pairs.neutral_text: We do not have any writings directly from Epictetus. Like G. H. Mead in modern times, he focused entirely on helping his students with their personal and intellectual problems. He let his students decide what parts of his teaching were important enough to record and preserve. Unlike Seneca and Marcus Aurelius, Epictetus did not apply Stoic ideas to his own personal experiences. He focused mainly on teaching moral philosophy, and only used logic and reasoning as tools to support this. He may have paid too little attention to physics and cosmology. Given this focus, he concentrated completely on the basic ideas of Stoicism, which are shown in the _Enchiridion_. Epictetus combined his personality entirely with logical thinking that aimed to live in agreement with nature.

pairs.stoic_text:
If you would improve, be content to be thought foolish and dull with
regard to externals. Do not desire to be thought to know anything; and
though you should appear to others to be somebody, distrust yourself. For
be assured, it is not easy at once to keep your will in harmony with
nature and to secure externals; but while you are absorbed in the one,
you must of necessity neglect the other.
pairs.neutral_text: If you want to get better, accept that other people might think you're stupid or boring when it comes to outside things. Don't try to make others think you're knowledgeable. Even if people see you as important, don't trust your own ego. Remember that you can't focus on both living according to your values and chasing external success at the same time. When you concentrate on one, you'll have to ignore the other.

pairs.stoic_text:
As the proposition, “either it is day or it is night,” has much force in
a disjunctive argument, but none at all in a conjunctive one, so, at a
feast, to choose the largest share is very suitable to the bodily
appetite, but utterly inconsistent with the social spirit of the
entertainment. Remember, then, when you eat with another, not only the
value to the body of those things which are set before you, but also the
value of proper courtesy toward your host.
pairs.neutral_text:
Here's the same text in plain language:

Just as the statement "either it is day or it is night" works well when you need to choose between options but doesn't work when you need both to be true, grabbing the biggest portion at dinner satisfies your hunger but goes against the social purpose of sharing a meal. So when you eat with others, don't just think about how the food will nourish your body - also consider the importance of being polite to whoever is hosting you.

pairs.stoic_text:
The first and most necessary topic in philosophy is the practical
application of principles, as, _We ought not to lie_; the second is that
of demonstrations as, _Why it is that we ought not to lie_; the third,
that which gives strength and logical connection to the other two, as,
_Why this is a demonstration_. For what is demonstration? What is a
consequence? What a contradiction? What truth? What falsehood? The third
point is then necessary on account of the second; and the second on
account of the first. But the most necessary, and that whereon we ought
to rest, is the first. But we do just the contrary. For we spend all our
time on the third point and employ all our diligence about that, and
entirely neglect the first. Therefore, at the same time that we lie, we
are very ready to show how it is demonstrated that lying is wrong.
pairs.neutral_text:
Philosophy has three main areas of study. The first area deals with putting principles into practice, such as "We should not lie." The second area involves proving these principles, such as "Why we should not lie." The third area examines the logical methods used in the second area, such as "Why this counts as proof."

This third area asks questions like: What makes something a proof? What is logical consequence? What is contradiction? What is truth? What is falsehood? The third area exists to support the second area, and the second area exists to support the first area.

The first area is the most important and where we should focus our attention. However, we do the opposite. We spend most of our time on the third area and put all our effort there, while completely ignoring the first area. As a result, we can lie while simultaneously being able to explain why lying is wrong.

pairs.stoic_text:
Be not elated at any excellence not your own. If a horse should be
elated, and say, “I am handsome,” it might be endurable. But when you are
elated and say, “I have a handsome horse,” know that you are elated only
on the merit of the horse. What then is your own? The use of the
phenomena of existence. So that when you are in harmony with nature in
this respect, you will be elated with some reason; for you will be elated
at some good of your own.
pairs.neutral_text: Don't feel proud about things that aren't actually yours. If a horse felt proud and said "I am beautiful," that would make sense. But when you feel proud and say "I have a beautiful horse," remember that you're only feeling proud because of what the horse is like. So what actually belongs to you? How you respond to and deal with things that happen in your life. When you handle life's events well and in line with what's natural, then you have a good reason to feel proud, because you're feeling proud of something you actually did yourself.
